name: 4th Place San Rafael Regional BABW Deck (5-3)
Credits on cards.
description: Its OK, rez that Pop-up Window I have NINE reoccurring credits to use for icebreakers!!! Went with the Anarch breaker suite, as they generally can work the best with low (or 0 credits) Scavenge to make sure the breakers are on top of an Omni-Drive and Stimhack for when you have to get in.

name: Corporate Sponsorship
description: Get your efficient breakers on Personal Workshop and then run and use the credits from the rezzed ice or a well timed Stim Hack to get your breaker suite out. Once out it will break any ice that is unrezzed with your ID credits, with the help of Toolbox and Cyberfeeder. An early RnD Interface can do work too if you run with no credits. Some corps wont rez to give you credits to pay the PW so you just get 2 cards. This deck is very "techy" so plan a turn or two in advance so that you are maximizing Nasir's ID.

name: Nasir, the Explorer.
Jinteki Personal Evolution: Garden of Mines
description:
This is the deck that has been keeping me at the top of the leader boards this week on the Official Stimhack League. It's a modified version of Chris's PE deck that won Cambridge reagonals. His version of the deck did not have enough money in it so I dropped the Shi.Kyū and Zaibatsu Loyalty for 3 medical research and changed around the ice a bit to make it more taxing. Lotus Field is awesome to plug any serious holes, especially with a Komainu on hq to keep siphons out. Komainu is awesome to threaten flatlines with, if they face check it they cant proceed to check anything. If they do they will die even in the best case scenario of finding an agenda.

To pilot the deck there are a few simple rules:

  • Always expect an account siphon, you have very little ice and it's pretty easy to get into archives unless you luck out and snipe the corresponding breaker to your HQ ice. You need to do your best to keep your credits above 9, that way you can take a siphon and keep Snare!s active. It is even worth it to take a siphon on the chin early and not rez your ice just to keep your traps alive.

  • Do your best to never hit zero credits and preferably never go below 4. The moment you hit zero credits the shell game is over. It's safe to check everything, and if you are playing an experienced runner they will take full advantage of this. It is NEVER worth it to score an agenda on the table and break your self. Trust the shell game to keep your agenda safe while you get some credits. I often will drop a Gila hands keep it on the board for an extra turns to get my self over 7 credits(you still want to try to stay above 9, but it's hard against siphons) before I score it.

  • Try to score one pointers. If you get a Gila Hands Arcology or a House of Knives the game is a lot easier to win.

  • Always try to get a Ronin on the table with at least 3 advancement tokens on it. Ronin wins me 50% of my games. With one emp, you can drop them if they ever go down to 3 cards with only 2 credits. I find criminals will do this when they siphon you to two and think they are safe from triple emp.

  • Play everything(except The Future Perfect). You cant get hung up about losing agendas or wondering if you should play a trap or an agenda. Just play everything as it comes up and the randomization of your deck will make it harder for the runner to pick out agendas. Sometimes they will be lucky and pick them out perfecty, sometimes you will flatline them on the first turn. It all comes down to luck.

  • Trust that the game is rigged. This deck is rather luck based, but I consider it like a casino. There are more traps than agendas, so you, as the house, have the advantage. Make sure the odds are stacked against them and you will win most of your games.

Until people figure out how to play against PE kill decks, I think this will be a strong archetype. And it will be a fun and viable archetype after everyone figures it out. I'm super happy to see PE come finally come into it's own after wanting to play a solid kill deck since I started playing netrunner.

Deck list and video of Chris's deck in action for the idea of how to play: http://stimhack.com/regionals-cambridge-ma-2014-67-players/

Update Took this to a store tournament and went undefeated as corp. All flatlines.

name: The Shwimp Trap
description: This deck is probably not super competitive, but instead is designed to punish super-aggressive Runners (such as my wife). Use Komainu or Psychic Field to deplete the Runner's hand, and then deliver a fatal blow with Neural EMP or a scored House of Knives. Wreck the Runner's tempo with Aggressive Secretary and Snare! Teach her she can't just run on every single remote you have and expect to get away with it. Err, I mean...the Runner.

name: Kate: The Sound of Silence
description: Get Replicator early

name: Grey Matter Bioroid v1
description:
Not sure if this has been made / published (I'm sure it has, if so here's another). Here's my non-blue HB deck!

It has absolutely no HB cards, and hopes to win a game someday. Its a pretty straightforward deck; gain credits; set out ice; advance when possible.

  • Agendas were very limited, but these all have a purpose on their own and can hopefully let you shift your focus towards the runner's weakness (PSF vs tag-me, mainly).

  • The standard econ is present (Hedge, PAD, Melange, Marked just for tax purposes). Jackson can hopefully let you recur 1x cards that were trashed/used, or get more Hedges, whatever you need of course.

  • Ice is catered to many situations. Put taxing ice on centrals (tags, credit grabs) and an etr or two if needed against multi-access / alternate success effects. Rainbow is there mainly as an early-game scout (lets you see what breaker they throw first, then act accordingly) and Chimera compliments it by letting you avoid what they bring out, hopefully netting you a 1-pointer.

  • Cyberdex is a soft counter to virus suites.

I don't expect this deck to win (we'll find out through testing.) In fact I'm going to update my decks as I play with them, with brief analysis. It'd be cool if this deck ends up doing well. Questions, comments and constructive criticisms are welcome.

name: Silhouette: In Nocte
description: Notoriety

name: Stirling: Inquisitor
description: Keyhole

name: Keep in touch.
description: The idea behind this deck is to include a lot of cards that mitigate the damage that any given corp could do. This is mostly done through attaining a decent link strength and installing resources and hardware that reduce the amount of meat damage the deck might sustain, as well as increasing hand size and drawing a lot of cards. The deck mostly uses breakers that keep their strength for the duration of a run (except for Ninja because Pipeline just won't cut it), with Crypsis thrown in as a catch-all breaker. Most of the deck's economy should come from searching up a Magnum Opus or grabbing a Kati Jones, then once link strength is up, in a slow drip through Underworld Contact.

name: CT - Wünder-rig 072514
GRNDL - Coal Roller 072514
description: *includes upstalk

name: 1% Inspiration, 99% Perspiration
description:
"Thomas Edison once said that genius was 1% inspiration and 99% perspiration. I think I've calculated it to be closer to .9345612% inspiration, actually." - The Professor

The Professor is probably my favorite Runner identity in the whole game, but until recently I had no idea how to build him. I hadn't really built decks on my own before, since I started playing Netrunner around the time that Honor and Profit came out. Now that I've started deckbuilding more frequently, I felt that it was finally time to make The Professor.

Econ: Freelance Coding Contract and Magnum Opus are the superstars of the deck. There are 20 total programs in the deck, meaning that 15 can be trashed with FCC before you need to think about using Levy AR Lab Access for recursion. So, in a nornal game I will usually use Quality Time before using FCC to get the maximum effect from it. Aesop's Pawnshop is in there as a one-of in case you need to make more room for progams down the road and Kati Jones should always have a spot in Runner decks.

Recursion: Levy AR Lab Access, Scavenge and Test Run are the primary means of program recursion. Quality Time guarantees that I hit one relatively quick, then I can hold on to it for later.

Programs: I've seen Professor builds in the past that didn't abuse his awesome ability. In this deck, you definitely get your influence's worth. The lone influence in the deck is slotted for Datasucker, which helps out the Dinosaurus/Morning Star combo, to get through those pesky barriers along with Paintbrush. The deck has multiple means of accessing agendas, whether it's Keyhole or Sneakdoor Beta combined with R&D Interface, Medium and Nerve Agent. The icebreakers include the centrals from Criminals and other classics. They're all relatively cheap to use and generally don't take up too much memory, which can be a problem for this deck.

In playtesting on OCTGN, the deck has been very solid, only having lost to a Fast Advance Cerebral Imaging build and a NEXT Design deck that managed to get a Wotan in front of an Archer and then 5 other ICE. The deck as a whole is very fun, though, and I will be tinkerig with it in the coming months as the Lunar cycle comes out.

name: Jinteki RP Advance and Deny
description: Use advancable assets and ice to store tokens and Mushin No Shin for efficient token generation and traps/gambits. Ice attempts to end the run on central servers early, and tax the runner/support the economy late. Trick of Light and cheap agendas power fast advancing, while ETR ice, Caprice Nisei and The Future Perfect help with denial.

name: Express, Oh!
description: I've been playing Express for a couple months now. This deck sustains its economy through running. It plays similar to Gabe, very aggressive from the get-go. It also forces the corp to defend all 3 central servers. As you can land Account Siphons on HQ, Index R&D, or make profitable runs on Archives with Security Testing and Desperado.

name: Anarch Fun
description: New Anarch deck I've been trying out.

name: Money for Nothing and your (micro)Chips for free V1
description:
Anyone get the title? :)

  • Get money, keep making money.

  • Use run events to get about everything you need. Keep and use until needed or run Planned Assault (s) when openings show up.

  • Escher is expensive, but with Planned Assault is strong and can really turn the tables. #Crypsis is also expensive, but with so much money works well until get out other breakers.

  • Question as to how many Prepaid VoicePAD (s) to put in.

Anyone see any better card combos or cards that could be taken out for a stronger deck?

name: The Toy Fortress
description:
We had a really fun day of drafting last saturday, building decks in the morning and playing all afternoon. Overdrive drafting is really solidly put together, i had doubts spending a bunch of money for drafting, but you get to see a lot of sinergy in the packs and build up janky decks that are a blast to play.

The draft was won by our friend @aldaris who cunningly drafted lots of traps, Jinteki-style, his style. In draft, after the first agenda has been scored, you just HAVE TO run everything that's advanced, period.

My first draft was a difficult decisionbetween Archer and Snare, and i went for the ICE, reasoning better to have a little extra ICE than be sorry and stuck with not enough to defend. I drafted HIves with extreme prejudice, the Hadrian Wall is actually Hive 4 . After getting passed SOme Elyza as late picks, the deck came together as big - ice , very taxing , compounded by Midway and Wisp , operating at low credits and rezzing with Eliza. Targeted Marketing acted more as a denial than a proper economy card. I can't seem to add agenda properly but i had a Future Perfect there too.

name: Aesop Fix It
description:
We had a really fun day of drafting last saturday, building decks in the morning and playing all afternoon. Overdrive drafting is really solidly put together, i had doubts spending a bunch of money for drafting, but you get to see a lot of sinergy in the packs and build up janky decks that are a blast to play.

The draft was won by our friend @aldaris whoo cunningly drafted lots of traps, Jinteki-style, his style. In draft, after the first agenda has been scored, you just HAVE TO run everything that's advanced, period.

After not seeing much breaker but Breach and a couple Atmans i decided to make a full switch to AI breakers with Alpha and what i could get.Luckily a Sucker came my way. Had i realized the Cerberus were so good i would have gone after them, they just eat ICE. Net Celebrity was a disappointment and did not pull its weight. Economy was based on multiple Tri-Maf acting as a risky Magnum Opus, and the search engine was made of Angel Arena, acting as a pseudo tutor, with Aesop recouping some of the cost of looking through the deck. If May or Wyldside showed up in time , even better, but they were just means to get the rig ad the Maf in place to run. Funny deck, i think we had seen 2 HQ interfaces among the 8 of us. Multiaccess is a luxury in drafting !

name: Whizzard is Making a Mess
Chess Wunderkind
Jinteki: An Open Book
Weyland: An Ode to Destruction
Andy Will Steal For Tags
HB: High Stakes Gambling
Fortress Bioroid
description:
This deck is meant to be taxing, first and foremost. There are 9 campaigns to force the Runner to prioritize their credits, lest the Corp walk into the midgame with overflowing coffers. One very important trick is laying Inazuma over Rototurret to ruin a runner's day, and possibly lock up a server or two. If click ICE is too porous, then Project Wotan and False Lead can serve as well as a Nisei MK II. Tenma Line also serves as a wonderful way to throw the Runner off their game when they may have their runs figured out.

I built this deck out of the cards I had on hand, so it's not even close to optimized, but it's served me really well. I can have a solid fortress built by midgame, and have enough credits to keep building and playing around.

-What might be some good new ICE arrangements in this deck?

-What can I invest in with lots of credits and most ICE rezzed?

-Are there any exceptional sentries I should have included?

name: Aggro Iain
description: So this is still a deck in progress, but the idea here is pretty analogous to a racing video game- if you fall behind you get a boost to help you catch up. So I play in a very aggro style, trying to score agendas, using Data Dealer to forfeit Shi-Kyu or 1-pt agendas for a quick burst to get into a server and turn it into more points, or at least deny the corp. Woman in the Red Dress helps me know when I should be hitting HQ or R&D, or helps me cycle through R&D a little faster, and Levy AR Lab Access helps me get back my Faerie or other cards and not worry about cycling through my stack so quickly. Scrubber helps in my meta with the large amount of asset economy. The Pheromones seems like it will get taken out for more Security Testing and I might trade an Emergency Shutdown for a Legwork. I admit to being a little weak at building decks but I've been enjoying this idea.

name: Tag and Fuck Up Your Whole Day
description:
Tag and Bag? Tag and Swag? No. We need to do more.

WIP

Suggestions very welcome.
